description: From Middle English mot, from Old English mot (“grain of sand; mote; atom”), but of uncertain ultimate origin. Sometimes linked to Spanish mota (“speck”) and English mud.
Compare West Frisian mot (“peat dust”), Dutch mot (“dust from turf; sawdust; grit”), Norwegian mutt (“speck; mote; splinter; chip”).

examples: What shall a Mote up to a Monarch rise?
An Emmet match an Emperor in might?

description: From Middle English moten, from Old English mōtan (“to be allowed, be able to, have the opportunity to, be compelled to, may, must”), from Proto-Germanic *mōtaną (“to be able to, have to, be delegated”), from Proto-Indo-European *med- (“to acquire, possess, be in charge of”). Cognate with Dutch moeten (“to have to, must”), German müssen (“to have to, must”), Ancient Greek μέδω (médō, “to prevail, dominate, rule over”). Related to empty.

verbs.description: mote (third-person singular simple present mote, no present participle, simple past and past participle must)

entries.meaning: (archaic) Forming subjunctive expressions of wish: may. [from 9th c.]
examples: ‘I shall not take Vengeance into my own Hands. The Goddess will do what She will.’ ‘So mote it be,’ said the Grandmaster.
a wardmote in the city of London

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A body of persons who meet for discussion, especially about the management of affairs.
(obsolete) A place of meeting for discussion.

description: From remote, with allusion to the other sense of mote (“a speck of dust”).

entries.meaning: A tiny computer for remote sensing; a component element of smartdust.
